unnormalised: RBI Announces New Guidelines for Gold Loans; Max LTV at 75%
normalised: R-B-I Announces New Guidelines for Gold Loans; Maximum L-T-V at seventy five percent

unnormalised: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has issued new guidelines regarding gold loans, effective from 01/04/2025. These guidelines aim to provide greater transparency and protection for consumers, particularly in rural areas where gold loans are a common source of financing. The most significant change is the maximum Loan-to-Value (LTV) ratio, now capped at 75%. This means that if you pledge gold worth Rs. 1 lakh, you can borrow a maximum of Rs. 75,000.
normalised: The Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) has issued new guidelines regarding gold loans, effective from first april two thousand and twenty five. These guidelines aim to provide greater transparency and protection for consumers, particularly in rural areas where gold loans are a common source of financing. The most significant change is the maximum Loan-to-Value (L-T-V) ratio, now capped at seventy five percent. This means that if you pledge gold worth rupee one lakh, you can borrow a maximum of rupee seventy five thousand.

unnormalised: Previously, some banks and NBFCs offered LTV ratios as high as 90%, especially under special schemes. While this allowed borrowers to access larger loan amounts, it also increased the risk of losing their gold if they were unable to repay the loan. Now, borrowers will need to deposit more gold to secure the same amount of money.

unnormalised: Interest rates on gold loans typically range from 9% to 26% p.a., depending on the lender and the loan amount. It's important to compare rates from different institutions before taking out a loan. Note that NBFCs usually charge slightly higher rates than Banks. Processing fees also vary. Look for the lowest "All-in-Cost"

unnormalised: The RBI is also mandating greater transparency in loan agreements. Lenders must now clearly disclose all fees and charges associated with the loan, including processing fees, valuation charges, and late payment penalties. Borrowers will also receive frequent reminders about their repayment schedules and outstanding amounts. Loan tenures are ranging from 6 months up to 24 months max in most of the Banks.
